To prove that
$$\frac{a-b}{a+b} = \frac{\tan(\frac{A-B}{2})}{\tan(\frac{A+B}{2})}$$ we
start with the sines law, which says that
$$\frac{a}{\sin(A)} = \frac{b}{\sin(B)}.$$ This implies that
$$a \sin(B) = b \sin(A)$$ We can write $\sin(A)$ as
$$\sin(A) = \sin(\frac{A+B}{2})\cos(\frac{A-B}{2}) + \cos(\frac{A+B}{2})\sin(\frac{A-B}{2}).$$
and $\sin(B)$ as
$$\sin(B) = \sin(\frac{A+B}{2})\cos(\frac{A-B}{2}) - \cos(\frac{A+B}{2})\sin(\frac{A-B}{2}).$$
Therefore, we have
$$a (\sin(\frac{A+B}{2})\cos(\frac{A-B}{2}) - \cos(\frac{A+B}{2})\sin(\frac{A-B}{2})) = b (\sin(\frac{A+B}{2})\cos(\frac{A-B}{2}) + \cos(\frac{A+B}{2})\sin(\frac{A-B}{2}))$$
Dividing both sides by $\cos(\frac{A-B}{2})\cos(\frac{A+B}{2}),$ we
have,
$$a (\tan(\frac{A+B}{2}) - \tan(\frac{A-B}{2}) )  =  b (\tan(\frac{A+B}{2}) + \tan(\frac{A-B}{2}) )$$
This gives us
$$\frac{a}{b} = \frac{\tan(\frac{A+B}{2}) + \tan(\frac{A-B}{2})}{\tan(\frac{A+B}{2}) - \tan(\frac{A-B}{2})}$$
Hence we find that
$$\frac{a-b}{a+b} =  \frac{\displaystyle{\frac{a}{b}}-1}{\displaystyle{\frac{a}{b}}+1} =
\frac{\tan(\frac{A-B}{2})}{\tan(\frac{A+B}{2})}.$$
